raw_text:
Howard pitches for UK ethnic vote
 
 Michael Howard is to make a pitch for Britain's ethnic vote urging people who feel "taken for granted" by Tony Blair to vote Conservative.
 
 He will say Conservatives "share the same values" as the UK's minorities. And that he wants to build a "better Britain" where everyone, whatever the colour of their skin or religion, can "make the most of their talents". But the Tory leader will argue against positive discrimination saying it is "outdated and unjust".
 
 "It sets family against family and it leads ethnic communities to doubt their own abilities," he will argue. Mr Howard - himself the son of immigrants - will acknowledge that racial discrimination still exists in the UK. "People from ethnic communities, for example, still earn less than their white counterparts," he will say before arguing the answer to helping everyone to get on was "free enterprise, free trade, free speech". The Tory leader will also call for religious tolerance arguing that Hindus and Sikhs as well as Muslims got "caught in the downdraft of Islamaphobia which was one of the terrible side effects of 9/11".
 
 Mr Howard will make his speech during a visit to support Tory Parliamentary hopefuls Robert Light and Sayeeda Warsi - "the first British Muslim woman" selected to run for MP as a Conservative candidate. He will attack Labour's record in government over issues such as tax and he will set out Tory plans for an immigration quota to be set by MPs. Mr Howard will also attack the Lib Dems for wanting to abolish faith schools, introduce compulsory sex education from the age of seven, and "give contraceptives out in schools from the age of 11". "So I say to all those people from ethnic minorities who feel Mr Blair and the Liberal Democrats take their votes for granted - come join us," he will say. Lib Dem president Simon Hughes branded Mr Howard "arrogant and wrong" for claiming the Tories were the "natural party" for Britain's ethnic minorities. "Given the Tories' considerably reduced support in urban areas, where many black and Asian Britons live, during their time in power, the evidence simply does not support his claims that the Conservatives are the party for these communities," he said.
llama3.2:1b: Howard will make a pitch for the UK's ethnic vote, arguing that Conservatives share values with minorities and want to build a "better Britain" where everyone can succeed. However, he will also criticize positive discrimination as outdated and unjust, and claim that free enterprise and trade are key to helping people from ethnic communities improve their lives. Howard will visit Tory parliamentary hopefuls Robert Light and Sayeeda Warsi, who were the first British Muslim woman to run for MP, and attack Labour's record on issues such as tax and immigration. He will also criticize Lib Dem plans for abolishing faith schools, introducing compulsory sex education, and giving contraceptives in schools from age 11.
llama3.2:3b: Michael Howard to urge ethnic minority vote, arguing against positive discrimination as outdated and unjust, saying free enterprise and free trade can help everyone make the most of their talents, calling for religious tolerance and introducing an immigration quota set by MPs, while criticizing Labour's record and Liberal Democrats' policies on issues such as tax, faith schools, and sex education.
gemma2:2b: Michael Howard will appeal to ethnic minority voters by arguing that the Conservative Party shares their values and wants a better Britain for everyone, regardless of race or religion. He will advocate against positive discrimination and argue for free enterprise as the solution to racial inequality.  He will also defend religious tolerance while criticizing Labour's record and calling for an immigration quota set by MPs. Howard encourages ethnic minority voters to join the Conservatives.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Howard pitches a case for UK ethnic vote to urge people from minorities who feel "taken for granted" by Tony Blair to vote Conservative. He argues that they want to build a better Britain where everyone has equal opportunities and no discrimination, while also calling for tolerance of different religions and allowing free speech. Howard will attack Labour's record in government over issues like tax, while suggesting the Lib Dems should abolish faith schools and give contraceptives out in schools from the age of 11.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Michael Howard will make a pitch for Britain's ethnic vote urging people who feel "taken for granted" by Tony Blair to vote Conservative, arguing against positive discrimination and calling for religious tolerance. He will also attack Labour's record in government and set out Tory plans for an immigration quota and abolish faith schools.
qwen2.5:3b: Michael Howard will make a pitch for Britain's ethnic vote urging people to consider voting Conservative, sharing values with UK minorities and promising a "better Britain" where everyone can succeed regardless of skin color or religion. He will argue against positive discrimination but support free enterprise and free speech. Howard will also call for religious tolerance and an immigration quota set by MPs. While attacking Labour's record on issues like tax, he criticizes Lib Dems' plans to abolish faith schools and introduce sex education. Howard claims the Conservatives are the natural party for ethnic minorities despite their reduced urban vote during their time in power.

smollm:1.7b:
The summary above is concise and conveys the main ideas of the text without including any supporting details or explanations. The key points include:

1. Howard's pitch for Britain's ethnic vote urging people who feel "taken for granted" by Tony Blair to vote Conservative.
2. His argument that Conservatives share the same values as the UK's minorities and want to build a "better Britain" where everyone can make the most of their talents.
3. His call for positive discrimination, arguing that racial discrimination still exists in the UK and that people from ethnic communities, for example, earn less than their white counterparts.
4. His criticism of Labour's record on issues such as tax, immigration, and faith schools.
5. His attack on Labour's record on faith schools, compulsory sex education from the age of 11, and giving contraceptives out in schools from the age of 11.
6. His claim that the Tories are the "natural party" for Britain's ethnic minorities, given their reduced support in urban areas where many black and Asian Britons live.

<think>
Alright, I need to help the user summarize a given text into a concise summary. The original text is about Howard pitches for Britain's ethnic vote, comparing Conservative values with UK minority values and discussing Tory arguments against it.

First, I'll identify the key points from each paragraph. The first sentence mentions Howard is making a pitch in support of the ethnic vote. He compares Conservatives to UK minorities, saying they share values like family and education.

Next, Howard makes a distinction between positive discrimination and negative. He argues that this can lead communities to doubt themselves but calls for better inclusive policies. He also mentions free enterprise as an answer.

The Tory leader responds by criticizing traditional values and calling for religious tolerance. They also point out the impact of events like 9/11 on Hindu, Sikh, and Muslim communities.

Howard then goes to support the Conservative candidate Robert Light and Sayeeda Warsi. He talks about labor's issues in tax policy and his defense of immigration quotas set by MPs.

Finally, Lib Dems respond that Howard's claims are not supported by their support in major cities, where many ethnic minorities live. He argues that the Tories aren't the natural party for these communities.

Now, I need to condense all this into a coherent summary without explanations or formatting. I'll make sure to capture each main idea and detail accurately.
</think>

Howard is advocating for Britain's ethnic vote by arguing that Conservatives share values with UK minorities, while he calls for better inclusive policies. Tory leaders counter with criticism of traditional values, urging religious tolerance and supporting initiatives like free trade and religion education. Howard supports Conservative candidate Robert Light and Sayeeda Warsi, who represents the first British Muslim woman running for MP. He emphasizes his defense of immigration quotas set by MPs. Lib Dems respond that Howard's claims are not supported in major cities with ethnic minorities.
tinyllama:1.1b: Michael Howard will make a pitch for the United Kingdom's ethnic vote, urging minority groups to feel "take advantage" of their potential and building a "better Britain". He will argue against positive discrimination, arguing that it is "outdated and unjust", and will criticize Labour over issues such as tax and immigration. In support of Conservative candidates, Howard will also address the issue of free speech and religious tolerance, urging tolerance towards all religions. He will call for a free market economy, with a focus on entrepreneurship and trade, calling for more initiatives in helping minority groups to succeed. Mr Howard's speech will be seen by many as an attempt to appeal to minority voters, and his proposals may help him secure the vote in the forthcoming UK general election.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Summary: A prominent British politician, Howard, is pitching his political party's stance on the UK ethnic vote to convince minority voters who feel disconnected from current policy. He argues for a more positive approach towards immigrants and believes that free enterprise, free trade, and religious tolerance are key elements in a successful nation. His speech will target specific issues facing minority communities such as taxes, immigration quotas, and the impact of politics on schools. The Lib Dem president, Simon Hughes, criticizes the Conservatives for their perceived disinterest in these areas and questions their claims of being the natural party for minorities.

Mr Howard will acknowledge that racial discrimination still exists in the UK but say the answer is free enterprise, free trade, and free speech. Mr. Light and Ms. Warsi, two Muslim women, have been selected as Conservative candidates, and Mr. Howard will attack Labour's record on issues such as taxation and argue that the Lib Dems want to abolish faith schools.
